lines.text: What do you think matters most for a good marriage?
A short memory.
Why did you get married?
I can't remember.
I had two big accidents in my life Diego, the trolley and you... You are by far the worse.
[last title card]
I hope the exit is joyful and I hope never to return. - Frida
I don't believe in marriage.
[crowd laughs]

No, I really don't. Let me be clear about that. I think at worst it's a hostile political act, a way for small-minded men to keep women in the house and out of the way, wrapped up in the guise of tradition and conservative religious nonsense. At best, it's a happy delusion - these two people who truly love each other and have no idea how truly miserable they're about to make each other. But, but, when two people know that, and they decide with eyes wide open to face each other and get married anyway, then I don't think it's conservative or delusional. I think it's radical and courageous and very romantic. To Diego and Frida.
I just want your serious opinion.
What do you care about my opinion? If you're a real painter, you'll paint because you can't live without painting. You'll paint till you die.
At the end of the day, we can endure much more than we think we can.

[upon learning Frida has been unfaithful to him with Leon Trotsky]
You've broken my heart, Frida.
It hurts doesn't it? But why? It was just a fuck, like a handshake.
No. I told you who I was when you married me.
Yes, you did, and I married you anyway. And, you promised to be loyal. You have been my comrade, my fellow artist... my best friend. But you've never been my husband.
I'd rather have an intelligent enemy than a stupid friend.
It was just a fuck. I've given more affection in a handshake.
You know, I don't believe in God... but I thank him every day that he kept you safe for me.
Oh really?... I tell you he's got a lot of explaining to do.
Did I tell you that I'm going to walk again.
Yes...
Did you believe it?
Of course I do.
You'd better, because you are going to miss it.
You've lost weight.
And you've lost your toes.
Is that why you're here? To offer your condolences?
I'm here to see how you are. How are you?
Tired of answering that question. Otherwise, like shit.
Who's there?
The ghost of Frida Kahlo.
I knew her!
How are you?
Lonely. Only you ghosts come to visit these days.
[Diego refuses to let her attend her show and is taking her prosthetic leg away]
Gimme back my fucking leg!
Is fidelity that important to you?
Loyalty is important to me. Can you be loyal?

[to Diego]
I want you to burn this Judas of a body. I don't want to be buried. I've spent enough time lying down. Burn it.

There was this skinny kid with these eyebrows shouting up at me, "Diego, I want to show you my paintings!" But, of course, she made me come down to her, and I did, and I've never stopped looking. But I want to speak about Frida not as her husband, but as an artist. I admire her. Her work is acid and tender... hard as steel... and fine as a butterfly's wing. Loveable as a smile... cruel as... the bitterness of life. I don't believe... that ever before has a women put such agonized poetry on canvas.

[as she's brought into the gallery]
Shut up, panzon. Who died?
Thank you.
For what?
For making a fat, old, crazy Communist a happy man.
I'm physiologically incapable of fidelity.
They say never trust a limping dog or the tears of a woman.
You've been my comrade, my fellow artist, and my best friend, but you've never been my husband.
I love a man with melones that are bigger than mine.
And I love a woman with cojones.
[first lines]
Careful, guys. This corpse is still breathing. Try to get me there in one piece.
[In the hospital after the accident]
Will she ever walk again?
Let's make sure she lives first.
Don't think I am going to sleep with you just because you took me under your wing.
Before you came along, I was painting murals and womanizing in peace.

[Carried in her bed, arriving at her exhibition in Mexico]
Shut up Panzone. Who died? Where is the music? You see doctor, I followed your orders. I didn't leave my bed.

[to the dog who has just urinated on his painting]
Lord Xolotl, Prince of darkness - you are the best art critic there is. Only you see what shit this country has made of me.
Sex is like pissing. People take it much too seriously.
I'm just keeping you honest, panzon.
Señor Rivera, I must ask you one last time to reconsider your position.
I will not compromise my vision.
In that case, this is your fee, paid in full, as agreed, but your services are no longer required.
It's my painting!
On my wall.
It's the people's wall, you bastard!
[last lines]
Happy silver.
It's not for two more weeks.
Seventeen days.
[They kiss for the first time and all the lights in the street turn on when they separate]
Did you arrange for that?
Cost me a fortune.
If I'm not good enough, I have to do something else to help my parents.
Unfortunately, I'm physiologically incapable of fidelity.
